text: Bottle. Pours dark amber/brown with small sticky yellow head. Aroma: sweetish, caramel, bread, raisins, butterscotch. Taste: sweet with some sbalancing sourish, caramel, bread, weak banana.Sweet finish.

Cloudy dark brown thin foamy tan head 
Aroma of malty sweetness some roast 
Flava is molasses and grain some hop 
Feels medium thick with lively foamy fizz 
Fin moderately dry and tangy

La cerveza es excelente, con un aroma dulce pero con sabor balanceado, en el paladar es completamente suave aun que su apariencia es turbia, el alcohol esta muy bien contenido entre el sabor y el aroma, podría tomarlo en una reunión social y terminar borracha sin darme cuenta, aromas a frutos secos rojos en mi parecer. ❤❤❤❤❤
UPDATED: MAY 13, 2017 Flaska systembolaget. Mörkt bärnstensfärgad. Söt och kryddig doft. Kåda och torkad. Ganska tunn smak. Trä, russin, plommon, lite choklad och bränt socker. Aningen torr.

On tap. Pours a hazy brown red with a thick light tan head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, candi sugar, light tart fruits, cherry, bready malt. Flavor of bready malt, lots of sweet fruits, cherry, date, fig. Very pleasant, lots of sweet fruity notes though its not overly sweet.
7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5)

0,75l bottle from Beergium. Clear, dark red brown beer with good, cloudy head. Aroma has raisins, yeast, dark fruits (plum mostly) and nice more fresh feeling. Taste has malts and bread, belgium yeast, plum and raisins. Also taste includes some fresher twist. Medium+ body, soft carbonation. Very nice, fresh and soft with dark fruits in nice balance. Lot like a Belgium dubbel.

Bottle shared with the fam, bottle sourced from Toft Vin, Copenhagen - pours dark amber brown with a nice beige covering. Sweet malty aroma and taste with a plethora of dried fruit, some caramel, treacle, brown sugar, yeasty and spicy accents into the close, tasty stuff.

On tap at Hops & Pie. Reddish amber appearance with an off-white head. Aroma of dark fruity esters, caramel malt, earth, light toffee and light candy sugar. Similar flavor, adding mild to moderate malt sweetness and a light earthy bitterness. Medium body with a pleasant finish. Well done.

Bottle @Curing Lillquists man-flu. Cloudy dark amber, offwhite froth. Dried fruit aroma, dark sugar. Very fruity. Malty flavour, more sweet dried fruit and dark sugar. Fluffy, warming and very drinkable.

Bottle. Pours cloudy lightish copper brown with airy but stable beige head. Clear aroma of malt and caramel, with notes of fruit and touches of yeast. Sweetish flavour of caramel malt and yeast, with notes of fruit and touches of hops. Creamy miuthfeel, despite the high carbonation. Estery, malty and slightly acidic afteraste. Very nice, especially for a Dubbel not made in Belgium.

Bottle, 8.0%. Mild fruity aroma. Hazy brown colour. Small stable off-white head. The flavour is quite malty, slightly fruity with some caramel and seemingly a little liquorice in the finish. As it warms, more fruity notes come out, dried fruit, coconut, but not overly sweet. Well-balanced.
Brown color, large beige head. Aromas of raisins, figs, caramel, oranges, yeast and slight spice. Taste of dried fruits, yeast, spices, alcohol, candy sugar and bananas. Balanced and good.

(bottle 3 years old )
Aroma:raisins,cherries,honey,bread
Appeara color,small dense off-white head.
Taste:sweet,flavour of bread,honey,dark fruits.
Palate:medium body,medium carbonation.
Overall: Lovely fruity dubbel could drink it everyday.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2017 Bottle. Candied fruits, molasses, honey, dried fruits, raisins. Sweet in taste. A little too pale, should be darker. Average body. Low carbonation. Very good. You can see the passage of time in taste - alcohol well hidden.
Fruity - peach, plum, maybe cherry, some spice, a bit of dark bread flavor underneath. Complex. Good.

750ml bottle from Systembolaget. Hazy dark brown, creamy white head, good lacing. Sweet estery aroma, figs, raisins, bread, spicy yeast and smoke. Medium-bodied, medium carbonation, smooth and mid-sweet mouthfeel. Sweet caramel malty taste with dired fruit, chocolate, cloves, cinnamon, banana, dates and figs. Mild warming finish.
Big bottle. Foggy icey brown. Fruity marzipan aroma. Chocolate, chalky malts, raisin taste. Totally solid dubbel. One of the best from the style. Lost Abbey for Prez.

0.75l bottle. Hazy dark orange/brown body, beige head. Aroma of dark sugar syrup, orange zest, raisins, figs and some cocoa. Taste of toast, dark sugar, figs, orange zest, raisins, cocoa and a touch of floral hops. Great beer for sure.

opalescent dark amber to mahogany colour, moderate sized creamy yellowish-beige-ish head; aroma of raisins soaked in liqueur, some figs, caramel notes, hints of cocoa and canned pear; taste of raisins, unripe plum and pear and hints of cocoa; great balance of bitterness, sweetness and sourness, but still somehow a bit immature
Poured from the tap. Amber brown with off white head. Belgian yeast, light raisin and dark fruit. Medium body.
@ Budapest, Csakajosor Pub. Dark amber color with medium off-white head. Strong syrupy aroma with red fruits. Taste, sweet malt, red fruits, candies, hops. Tasty.

Aroma: dried fruits, prune, some stonefruit and anise, honey
Taste: medium sweet, stonefruit, malty, caramel, anise, alcohol

Moody with rest of hops, small steady head. Aroma: honey, dry fruits, plum, some belgian notes. Heavy to medium sweetness, medium to full body, medium bitterness. Flavour: honey, bit fruity; peach, bitbalcoholic finish.
Well done dubbel. Figs, candi sugar, dark fruit, pleasant spices, yeast. Medium bodied. As it should be done.

I poured it from the bottle into a glass. It pours reddish brown with a fluffy, beige head and lots of lacing. The aroma is dark fruit, sugar, and alcohol. The taste is raisin, prune, plum, some chocolate, and Belgian yeast. Its very smooth and subtly sweet. This is very good.

750 mL bottle from Ridgewood Wine & Beer Co., Raleigh. Brownish-orange pour with a frothy off-white head. Aroma of raisin, prune, and Belgian candi sugar. Taste offers the expected fig, raisin, and prune flavors but adds further depth with notes of oak, tobacco, and chocolate. A well done dubbel.

Piana obfita, żółta, nieco mydlana, utrzymuje się w postaci chmurek i ładnie zdobi szkło. Barwa miedziano czerwona, opalizująca. Aromat słodki, przyjemny, rodzynkowy, karmelowy, miodowy, w tle lekko ziołowy. W smaku półsłodko, tu również sporo rodzynek, dojrzałych winogron, daktyli i fig, do tego karmel, toffi i miód, owoce kandyzowane, przyprawy, ziołowa, nieduża goryczka, pikantność w posmaku. Wysycenie wysokie do średniego, lekka cierpkość i szorstkość pestkowa na języku, całkiem pijalne, nie ulepkowate, nie gęste, choć oczywiście pełne w odbiorze.

Smaczny, ładnie pachnący dubbel, klasyczny, choć wydaje się dość lekki jak na styl - taka trochę "codzienna", fajnie przyswajalna wersja Judgment Day...

Aroma:

Medium/heavy aroma of malts, caramel, Belgian yeast, dried fruit, chocolate, bread, roasted malts and spices.

Appearance:

Turbid/opaque dark orange/brown beer with heavy yeast and with a medium beige head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts medium sweet with malts, caramel, Belgian yeast, dried fruit and chocolate; ends slightly bitter and dry with bread, roasted malts and spices.

Overall:

This beer is intense, complex and balanced. There is so much going on in this beer, it is insane. The appearance is amazing, the aroma strong and the flavour rich. This is (one of) the best beer(s) this style can produce.
Pours hazy brown with tan head. Aroma is burnt sugar and cake. Flavour is medium sweet, light to medium bitter, spices and cake.

I am not sure about this one because it tasted and smelled yeast very much. 
Deep brown body with an one finger beige head. It smells yeast,malt,fruits .The taste is yeast,fruits,malt,some caramel.The carbonation is mild and the body is medium and silky.It is sweet and a little bitter at the end.Quite nice beer but I have to drink it again.

Deep brown, opal with a light tan head and good lacings. Aromas of stone baked bread, raisins, sultanines, touch of liquorice and wet wood develops. Fine carbonation lightly tangy with a moderate slick texture and a surprisingly slender body. Malty bready sweetness with a light herbal bitterness and some fruity yeast flavours develop. Moderately pleasantly lasting finish. Well balanced.
Very nice and smooth. Reddish brown color and cloudy. Yeasty and some Belgian spices. Nice carbonation for style. Sugars do not overwhelm like some. Tap

Poured from a 25 OZ corked bottle into a tulip glass. The appearance is a clear reddish brown with a thick off-white head. The aroma is fruit, bread and some alcohol. The taste matches the aroma perfectly. A very good beer.

From 32gp. In La Trappe chalice. Watching Los Soprano 3x12-13. Raisin pretty noticeable in mouth and taste. A bit earthy. Bitterness bigger than usual in the style. Good but its missing some punch to be memorable. More cloudy than desiderable at the end

(Bomber bottle where the label says "1 pint 9.4 fl oz", weird; Of course there is no BBD but at 8% ABV, who needs it?; Got it from Tapperiet Brus) Poured at cellar temperature into a Maisel & Friends stemmed tulip glass reveals a clear dark brown body with one finger of tan head that fades somewhat after a few minutes leaving film and lace. Aroma has notes of biscuit, dust and aniseed. Not a lot of dark fruit in there as far as I can tell. Not that sweet either, which is actually fine by me. Oily texture, soft carbonation, medium body and a lingering, grassy ryebread bitter finish. Flavour is on the bitter side of things with some biscuity notes. Im not really into the kind of complexity that this beer offers. I was never really into the style and this beer doesnt manage to convince me otherwise even if it seems a bit atypical for the style.
Sweet bready, malty aroma. Pours a copper color with a great off-white head. Full-mouthed, almost chewable body. A nice rounded dubbel.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 butla 0.75, swieza razej warka (ale w sumie hamerykance nie napisali z kiedy). Tradycyjnie dla lost abbey - nawet fajnie te maluneczki wygladaja... Samo piwo tez niebrzydko zreszta - miedziano-burgundowo-brazowawe, nieco metne, ze niezbyt trwala ale ladna, gesta nieco kremowa piana. Aromaty... slodka mieszanka ciemnych owocow - swiezych i suszonycha (w szczegolnosci wisnie, rodzynki, moze ciut ciut fig kandyzowanych), troche karmelu, troche jakies ziolowosci przyprawowej blizej jak dla mnie niesprecyzowanej. troche ciasteczkowo-chlebowe moze tez. Nie jest to tak intensywne, jak mozna by chciec. Daje przy okazji dosc slodkie wrazenie calosci. w ustach srednio ciala, nieco lepko i syropowo, slodkawo, Alko jest ladnie ukryte, jednak nie az tak ladnie, jak w belgijskich pierwowzorach. wysycenie niby niskie, ale takie drobne, ze poszczypuje az ciut w jezyk. Bardzo dobre piwo z jednej strony, ale z drugiej takie i lepsiejsze mozna kupic za mniej niz polowe ceny, co troche jakby ryje percepcje..Ocena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).
Draft sample. The beer is a clear amber with a beige head. Toffee and nuts. Some caramel, brown sugar. Sweet and nutty. Medium body and low carbonation.
Draft - Raisin and fruity plum. Clear Amber with a rich beige head. Sweet raisin, touch of roast coffee and toffee sweetness.

It pours dark amber with red hues and a light brown moderate head. It has a sweet malt aroma that is moderate, moderate fruit, raisins, and cherries. There is also a low spicy element, caramel and toast. A touch of floral finishes out the aroma. It has a sweet malt flavor or caramel and toast. There are moderate cherry and raisin flavors. This is low spice and floral hints. The balance is toward the malt. It has a medium full body with a bit of alcohol warmth in the finish.
A: Deep brown with some red notes. Huge off white head. N: Raisins, plum, caramel T: Raisins, caramel O: Decent...

Bottle shared with ippopotamo36. Pours amber, a bit unclear, with a medium and persistent off-white head. Aroma of caramel, raisins, hops. Flavour is medium sweet with a good bittet end, licorice, ashes. Medium body, light carbonation. Evocative.

Bottle in Rome-Italy. Thank you Mortlach. Dark Amber cloudy pour, medium and tick ivory foamy head. Nose: raisins, residual feel of caramel and dry meat. Mouth: a bit tobacco, ashes, a bit medicine. Did not get it!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, 750ml. A cloudy brown beer with minimal brown head. Aroma is of dried fruits (especially raisins), alcohol and wood. Taste is moderately bittersweet with faint carbonation and astringency. Light to medium bodied and with a finish that reminds me of raisins. Not a very strong character; quite thin actually.

Bottle, 75cl. Opaque brownish with a minimal head. Deep aromas of dried fruits, notes of toffee, alcohol. Medium to full bodied with moderate carbonation. Medium sweet with medium bitterness. Deep raisin and fruity flavors into a bitter alcohol finish. Very nice.

Pours deep red with a bubbly beige head. Aroma is very rich raisins with an almost fruitcake but not boozy in any way. Taste is upfrnt (slightly) burnt raisins, with a good helping of sweetness and the yeasty notes (which I dont actually enjoy too much) are less prominent initially - only one warmed up to the estery banana/spicy notes come in. The best dubbel I have had but I am far from a fan of the style and I would choose to have this slightly chilled to suppress the (not excessive at all for the style) yeasty notes which admittedly defeats the object of a dubbel. The additions of the raisins elevates this massively to me and another piece of The Lost Abbey jigsaw is in place.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar Aarhus. Pours light hazy brown with a big offwhite head. Aroma is sweet, malty, nutty, dark fruits; raisins, plums, figs. Yeast, caramel. Taste is sweet at first, dark fruits, lots of raisins, yeasty, also some lighter fruits, grape-like sweetness, light bitterness, malty.

W zapachu głównie rodzynki, suszone figi i daktyle. W tle trochę fenoli i przypalonego karmelu. W smaku bardzo wytrawne, dość fenolowe, wyłażą tak suszone owoce w sporych ilościach, jak i guma balonowa. Wysycenie dość wysokie. Bardzo dobry dubbel, braciszkowie z niejednego klasztoru w Belgii by mogli pozazdrościć.

Keg at Route CBC, CBC Clapham, 02/10/15. Reddy caramel brown coloured pour with a lasting creamy head. Aroma is earthy honey and brown sugars, brown bread. Flavour is composed of sticky brown sugars, tasty enough, mellow belgian yeast, cinnamon and some spicy wood in the finish. Palate is semi sweet with highish carbonation. Decent.

Not sure how old this bottle is, but pulled it out of my cellar and it was between 4-7 years old. Medium brown color. Lots of port and dark fruit, milk chocolate. Low carbonation that is a bit uneven, but flavors have really integrated well. Very malty, nice lingering finish of port and dark fruit. Nice.
Tap at lost abbey, san marcos. Hazy dark brown color, white head. Aroma has typical dubbel notes, raisins, plums, caramel. Full body, raisins, sweer fruity notes, some chocolate.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2015 from bottle to tulip. Aroma of straw and slight fusel alcohol heat. Dark fruit show late and moderately. Aroma rounds out nicely as it warms and marries. Clear garnet-brown with light brown head that coats the top as a dusting with moderate large bubbles around the collar. Taste is chocolate, fig and slightly old dark fruit. Residual sweetness is slightly too sweet.

Oct 2015 - Keg at Route CBC, Clapham. Dark orange / brown, still, small foamy tan head. Aroma is plastic, Viennese whirls. Body is medium to light, tingly carbonation, slightly foamy. Taste is biscuity, raisin, a bit papery and metallic into the finish. Average for style.
Bottle at BeerGeek. Dark amber color with medium off-white head. Strong syrupy aroma with red fruits. Taste, sweet malt, red fruits, candies, hops. Tasty.
Bottle from beer geek. Hazy amber colour, stable head. Aroma is complex. Raisins, dried fruits, malts, chocolate, caramel. Taste is much the same. Some alcohol. Very complex beer. Very good.

Bottle at Beergeek Bar shared by Kazator, many thanks! Excellent beer, fully malty, very smooth, fruity, raisins, alcohol hidden well. Balanced also in way of basic flavours, sweet, but also warming alcohol and moderate bitterness.

Keg at Route CBC, CBC Clapham, 02/10/15.
Murky mahogany brown topped with a decent beige swirl and edgeing.
Nose is rich fruits, toasted brown sugar, grain, light spice, brown bread, biscuit.
Taste comprises dark fruits, raisens, earthy, bitter fruit, spice, fruit loaf, toffee, Belgian yeast esters.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Ok for style.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Pours a dark golden brown with small fizzy head. Aromas of fruit and caramel with a touch of tobacco. Flavors of dark fruits, tobacco, and some chocolate. Bottle was kinda flat, would love to try a effervescent one...
Bottle from Julios. Poured into a snifter. A deep purplish-brown color. Little to no head. Low carbonation. Earthy-fruit aromas and flavor. Sweet thin body. Rather disappointing.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is raisins, prunes, spiced fruit cookies. Taste is fruity malts, creamy and crisp, deep dark fruits with some nice freshness. Very balanced. Probably a really great introduction to a Belgian-style Dubbel...but also has staying power.

Tap at Route CBC. It pours deep red-brown with a decent white head. The nose is toasty, earthy, some spice, caramel, dried fruits and rich fruit cake. The taste is toasty, earthy, toasted grass, caramel, toffee, dried fruits, candied peel, some alcohol warmth and a touch of Rivita. medium body and average carbonation. Doesnt quite have the depth I was hopping for. OK, but there a plenty Belgian varieties that way better.

Bottle. Deep red browny. Bit sweet bready, plummy dark fruity, yes, raisins to some extent too, abbeyish yeasty character on nose. Med bodied, very smooth, real easy drink. Some spices, clove, some cinnamon. Sweet bready / dry cakey. Cola. Love the texture / palate, real smooth, hides the abv well.

Où, Quand, Comment :  Bouteille. Mondial de la bière. 


Visuel :  
Couleur : ambrée foncée. 
Apparence : semi-voilée. 


Arôme :  
Levures fruitées (ffruits confits), caramel sucré, légèrement fruité, notes de noix.


Goût :  
Entrée de bouche : levures fruitées (fruits confits) et légèrement épicées avec des notes de noix.
Un support sucré de caramel avec une légère amertume de houblon herbeux et quelques notes de sucre brun.

En bouche :  

Corps : moyen.
Effervescence : moyenne.
Texture : moyennement crémeuse aux petites notes sirupeuses.
Finale : moyenne-longue, composée dun goût fruité avec des notes de houblon floral et dalcool

Bottle to a wine glass
Yeast, bread, currants, rose, and caramel malt. Hazy brownish amber with a thin, creamy light tan head. Malt, bread, yeast, mace, and clove. A quite nice beer.
Pours copper with quickly dissipating tan head. Smells of apricot and raisin. Smooth finish, its a quality beer I would drink often if given the opportunity.
Dunkelbraun. In der Nase Dörrobst, süß, rote Früchte, Malz. Am Gaumen dunkle Trockenfrüchte, Honig, leicht röstig, belgisch hefig, recht süß, etwas dünn, leicht trocken. Okay.
Bottle; pours dark amber with an off white head; sweet aroma of malt, caramel, and dark fruits; bittersweet with dark fruits, caramel, and malt; dry finish with a hint of spices; nice dubbel
Nothing much disappoints from this brewery. Prune fig and dried fruit aroma. Mild malty evident. Great palate and aftertaste of sweet plums. Fantastic.
Prune and fig on a dusty brown pour with white poof head, sweet flavor with raisin and prune. Finishes a little thick not bad.

Bomber - pours a nice mahogany brown with a fluffy off white head that quickly dissipates. It smells of rich sweet malts, dark ripe fruit, a hint of baking spice and herbaceousness. A mouthful is layered with fig, prune, tart cherry, caramel like malts and a touch of earthiness. Like fall in a bottle.
Bottle, 750 ml from Svijet Piva, Zagreb. Shared with JFK10000 and others. Pours dark amber with medium off-white head. Caramel malty, dried fruits, bit spicy. Alcohol well hidden.

On tap at the GA Chaper Room. Pours muddy brown, with a rocky, beige head. The nose is caramel, cloves, pecans, some light oak, and pine sap. Sweet and malty up front, with a good bit of hoppy bitterness, especially as it warms. Medium to heavy body, with a creamy and smooth mouthfeel. Lightly bitter aftertaste. This is a pretty nice dubbel, with good malt character, the hops are more aggressive than Id like for the style.
Brown with no head. Draft pour at Lost Abby /port brewing. Prune and berries. Not my style but decent.

A great dubbel from Lost Abbey, so far a good track record from this brewery. A malty, deeply fruity and sugary brew. Almost like a dark dessert wine on the palate due to the presence of heavy raisin and fig notes. The aftertaste is of a deep malt, yeast and alcohol with the candied taste lingering. Overall makes for a delicious combination that is definitely to be savored. An excellent example of the Belgian style of brewing and another fine selection from Lost Abbey.

Tap at the brewery. Pint glass. Deep amber color with minimal off white head. Aroma is muted but has some nutty, roasted aspects. Taste is heavy on malty sweetness with caramel and subtle dark fruits. Coats the mouth in sugars. Spices are present. Solid dubbel by a brewery that exceeded expectations. Try it.

Sampled on draft at 3R6P this beer poured a cloudy dark brown color with a medium sized foamy beige head that left a bit of lacing. The aroma was malty, a bit toasty and had hints of caramel, root beer and dark fruits. The flavor was bitter, malty and toasty with caramel, wood, a bit of dark fruits and root beer. Medium length finish. Medium body. Ok.
Bomber. Very murky orange amber pour with a dense head. Rich raisin, yeast, creamy dense palate. Yummy stuff!

750mL bottle, poured into a snifter. The aroma is a rich, sharp fig and/or grape with a hint of alcohol, a light copper, and a light roast and light caramel late. It pours a murky brown red with a dense, off white head that has moderate retention and lace. The taste is a medium high bitter with a medium sweet. Its creamy and oily with a fizz carbonation and a full, figgy boddy with light notes of biscuit. As it warms, flavors of caramel and tart grape juice become more apparent with a finish of pepper spice and copper, as well as wood. The dry aftertaste is long, bitter and astringent with a dry malt character, toast, pepper, and light copper.

Draught at the Lost Abbey, San Marcos, CA. 
Cloudy red colour with a small off-white head. 
Sourness, raisins, burned bread, malt and some sugar in the aroma. Complex aroma.
The flavour is burned bread, malt, dark fruits, sugary sweetness and some sourness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at the brewery. Pours hazy copper with a fizzy beige head. Tastes like sweet dried fruit, bubblegum, light yeast, and sweet doughy malt. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like dried fruits, yeast, some bubblegum, banana, and bready malt.

From the corked, caged 750 ml bottle. 2014 batch. The pour is a deep amber-reddish color with a small head. The aroma has a malty character with cooked brown sugar and a sort of cellar-muskiness. Medium body, There is a modest sweetness but it feels more boxy and musky. A dark fruit (raisins) character. Mild finish.

Cloudy brown orange body with a medium bubbly frothy off-white head. Aromas of raisins and plums and other sour fruits. Tastes of sweet candied booze with light caramel and floral notes. Medium-full body.

Lágy és példaértékűen krémes habot fejleszt a Lost Abbey dubbele; sötét karamell színe csalogató illatokat rejt, törökméz és füge, mogyoró és mazsola, banános élesztő egyenes aromái bukkannak fel egyszerre. Komoly tartalom fogad minket ezt követően, a krémes illatokat határozottan élénk, kiegyensúlyozott és kerek mondanivalójú szerkezet követi. Friss zamatú, élettel teli dubbel, melyben a lágyan pörkölt maláta és puha, selyemcukor-forgáccsal megszórt élesztő karaktere domborodik ki leginkább, nem nélkülözve viszont a komló jól felismerhető lenyomatát. Leginkább mégis amolyan belga stílustanulmányként funkcionál, ahol a kategória ismérveinek minden fontos komponense képviselteti magát, kiugróan egyedi jellemvonások nélküli, klasszikusan elegáns apátsági jellegű főzetet alkotva.

Bottle. Popped off the cork and a white smoke poured out, like fog over a moonlit swamp. The smell hit me in the face from two feet away. If smells were colors, this would be purple - -a deep, sweet smell almost like grape juice thats been left in the sun. The liquid glugs out a deep orangey brown with a giant pale bubbly head. Champagne bubbles surge up from the depths. This is a good-looking beer. The flavor starts with sweet grape/raisin flavor, while prunes and other dark fruits are also apparent. Theres a slight alcohol warmth, while a light bitterness hits in the aftertaste and a sour tanginess lingers on the sides of the tongue -- my favorite part of this beer, along with the very creamy mouthfeel. It took a while to get around to swallowing, because I couldnt stop swishing this beer around.
Bottle share on the buse. Light raisin nose, some general malt sweetness. Taste is a light malty sweetness with a touch of breadiness. Pretty solid.
Sweety and nutty Belgian aroma. Pours murky orange-brown with a bubbly head. Taste is sweet and nutty with hints of raisin.
Raisins and plums along with sme raspberry and many other sour fruits. Dark brown good mouthfeel and carbonation. Flavors of fruit and tart were pretty intense. Good now may be better over time.

[2/22/15] Draught at Port Brewing/Lost Abbey in San Marcos. Dark amber-brown. Aroma of dark fruits, yeast, caramel and a mild sourish olive note. Sweet flavor, yeasty, slightly tart, with dark fruits and spiciness. Medium-bodied.

Bottle from Atlanta shared with Nick and Brian at home. Snifters. Pours a dark hazy brown with an active pillow head. The aroma is moderate with raisins, dark fruits, caramel, and light Belgium yeasts. Taste is dark fruits like figs and raisins, candied sugars, Belgium yeasts, and cookie dough malts. Active carb, somewhat a malty and fruit finish. Good.

A dark beer, reddish brown, a head is quite big,dense and blond. Aromahas sweet strawberries, dark fruits, plums and raisins, some bread and perfume. Taste has soft fruits, plums, strawberries, hint of dry bread. Taste has also hint of fresh perfume. Medium+ bodied, mild carbonation, smooth palate. The great Dubbel, fresh, aromatic, and tasteful.

Bottled 750ml. -Courtesy of Fran (thanks!), shared with Marko, kajser27 and Fran of course. Nice dark amber coloured, medium sized pale beige head, caramel and raisins in the nose. Toasted malt, caramel, dried fruits, some spices and raisins with mild alcohol notes in the finish. Tasty one but pretty basic.

Brown colored with ruby hue, medium to low off white head. Aroma is strong raisins, sweet and toasty. Same goes for taste sweet malty, raisin jam on a burnt toast. Some toffee as well. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Well hidden alcohol. Very nice! Thanks to Fran!

Thanks to whoever brought it... Fran? Ogi? Dunno. But thanks anyway! :) Poured a dark amber-brown body with a small off white head. Aroma... yeah, definitely raisins, heavy maltiness, light alcohol... pleasant overall. January 6th, 2012 - The Lost and Found combines two of my favorite beer characteristics: Lost Abbeys brewing style, and the Belgium Dubbel. The rewards are theoretical, and a quick sample of the beer reveals that they are also empirical. The nose overflows with dark cherries, rich and freshly shaved chocolate, and the arcane scents of Burley pipe tobacco. The flavor carries over from the nose, dripping with overripe cherries, roasted pecans and even a little bacon. All the tastes and flavors emanating from this brew are fascinating in combination, but the only thing that holds the Lost and Found back is that they are a little muddied - the flavors are never especially pronounced, and they never pop. Instead, they sort of swirl lazily and without direction. Overall, this is an excellent treat, but it s also in heated competition with American and Belgian counterparts. Even then, this beer is a testament to Lost Abbeys brewing skills.

Pours a rich mahogany with off white head. Aromas of dark fruits, raisins and plums. Raisiney  taste with some fig, plum, spice and sweet malts. Finish is medium sweet. Great Dubbel made right down the street!

Csak a jó sör, Budapest.
Egészen sötét, vörösesbarna, mahagóni színe van. Habja vékony, krémes, enyhén sárgás és igen kitartó. Illata aszalt gyümölcsös, karamellás, vaníliás és igen malátás. Aszalt füge, datolya, szilva, mazsola, e mellé  egy kis fűszer, egy csipetnyi fahordós beütés, sok maláta egy kis komlóval + a belga élesztő és már csorog is lefelé a torkunkon ez az ital. Elég testes és szénsavas, a magas alkoholtartalom szépen elvan rejtve benne. Utóíze igen száraz, fás, olyan, mintha kakaóporba szippantanánk. Nagyon érdekes dubbel, ami nem olyan édes, mint a legtöbb testvére. Kellemes itóka.

750 ml bottle @ Patricks. Slightly hazy reddish body with a moderate off-white head. Aroma is vinous, dry fruit and caramel. Flavor is sweet and fruity, malt and caramel. Some bitterness, very smooth. Fine body, good aftertaste. A very pleasant beer.

Poured into a Duvel tulip from a 750ml caged and corked bottle with no freshness date.

A: Clear deep garnet body with a thin creamy looking tan head. Very appealing looking.

S: Slight dark fruits with a sugar sweetness, raisons do come through as do some apples, but well balanced.

T: Very sweet, sugar and raison flavor from start to finish with light chocolate notes. This is good and easy to drink.

M: Full bodied with decent amount of fizzy mouth expanding carbonation.

O: This is a good brew, but overall Im not too impressed. Theres a great delicate balance to this though with a nice complexity.

Bottle.  Pours a reddish brown color with a cream colored head.  Aroma of caramel and dark fruit with a hint of grape, toffee and Belgian spice.  Sweet caramel taste with a dark fruit and candi sugar.  Some spice and hops in the middle and toffee on the back end.  Good dubbel.

750 ml bottle. Huge chocolate fudge nose, raisin, fig. Chewy as hell. Dry flavor of chocolate, raisins, and some funk. Lots of dry fruits. Crisp and dry like a biere de garde. Could use some more age.

Pour is a light mahogany color with a small bone white heat, of maybe a finger and a half quickly diminishing. Nose is of dark fruits and raisins mainly. Taste is very similar to the nose minus the raisin distinction, which makes it slightly more hard to, discern without being known. Overall palate is there but nothing exceptional, though good overall.

Bottle, 75cl corked, at Patricks. It pours a big, dense, light beige head over a lightly dim copper colored body. Nice lacings left. The aroma has a solid dose of dried fruits, some caramel and chocolate and a touch of alcohol. Sort of sugary. It is full-bodied, sweet, warming and pleasantly bitter in the mouth. Dried fruits and some chocolate and caramel. A touch of yeast too. A really pleasant one, smooth and tasteful. 120121
Smooth Ale with a blend of caramel, light raisins, bread, grapes and some roasted malt.  Seems to disappear too quickly.

Pours hazy orange brownish with no head. Aroma is dark sweet fruits, raisins, caramel, ripe plums, quite sweet traditional belgian sweetness. Taste is slight oxidized, some astringent bitterness in the back. Still very sweet and sugary with lots of dark fruits.

Aroma of malt, caramel, spices, yeast and malt. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, cacao, hay and fruitiness. Medium body, average carbonation. Nice balanced beer.

Dark amber pour, light brown head. Aroma has a strong raisin quality, dark fruits, leather, hazelnuts, dark sugar, slight hops and oxidation. Taste is much the same, a bit more roasted, and a good deal of sweetness, some off oxidation and slight astringent tartness in the finish.

Head: very small , almost nothing , off-white 
Colour: caramel brown 
Smell: dried fruits, bit of booze, grassy , candy sirup/caramel, malts, bit of burnt caramel 
Taste: start is bitter malty followed by a boozey wineous taste, second is sweetsour with a dried fruity undernote , end is quite bitter with a hopy flavour and a dry mouthfeel , aftertaste is a bit of chocolat , nice  !
Tap.  Ruby amber pour.  Aroma of coffee grounds.  Taste of coffee grounds and raisins.

Courtesy Secret Santa. Aroma was alright. Fig and raisin intertwine with an annoying metal smell. Pour was a nice murky dark brown with reddish hues and a one finger light tan head. Taste was nice. Figs and raisin are the predominant flavor. As it warmed, nutmeg and brown sugar emerged. What I loved about this beer was the strong and aggressive carbonation. It bit the cheeks and mouth nicely. The candi sugar and Belgian yeast come up in the aftertaste. Has a slightly American flavor, but one of the best dubbels Ive tasted from our side of the pond
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Caged and corked bomber, poured into goblet. Hazy brown with orange highlights, nice foamy white head with okay lacing. Murky appearance. Nose is raisins, apricot, slightly sour notes. Reminds of pinot noir. Earthy notes sneaking through. Taste is quite subdued for the strength: strong raisin, slight plum and fig, hints European hops flickering in and out. Some tingle from the carbonation, but a very soft mouthfeel overall. Not transcendent, but a hell of a beer.

A deep purplish-red underlies the mud brown body. Small foamy head. Aroma is juicy grapes and other dark fruits including raisin and prune. Taste is rich dark chocolate, raisin, prune and fig. Some caramely chocolate malt lingers through its fine medium-heavy balance. Aftertaste of dark chocolate and toffee. Alcohol presence is extremely mild. Clearly a great dubbel.

Savannah, Ga - Five Points Liquors - 750 ml cage-corked bottle. Pours a dark copper-chestnut brown, slightly murky with a lazy soft white head that clings to the sides. Pleasant aroma with some canned baked brown bread, molasses and raisins. Flavor is on the mellow side with some raisin-like sweetness, some molasses, brown sugar hint of chocolate in the back end. Nice thick mouthfeel. Nice nightcap.

Deep misty mauve brown pour medium head aromas dark fruits liquorice port raisins candy hops flavours smooth port plums raisin yeast sweetness medium bitter and some lovely figs sweet juicy ale good flavour and body finish aftertaste dark fruit candy sweetness lasting bitter port taste raisin very pleasing dubbell

750 ml bottle, bottled on date of 11/23/10.  Served in a DFH Signature glass, the beer pours a murky ruby red/brown color with about an inch tan head.  Head retention and lacing are both decent enough.  The aroma is nice and malty, the brew smells like dark fruit (mostly raisins, along with some cherries and figs), nuts, brown sugar and toffee.  Taste is similar to the aroma, but theres a bit of spice noticeable too.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its creamy and has moderate carbonation.  Its also smooth and goes down easy.  I think this is a solid overall brew, and at $8.99 a bottle Id buy it again the next time I see it.  Certainly worth a try.

bought in CO; had on Tday;  WOW; first Lost Abbey and will try to get more.  this seemed to be more of a strong american ale than a dubbel?  but great nonetheless.  dark amber pour.  aroma of dark fruits (bread?).   Taste was a perfect mix of the dark fruits, some hops with no alcohol taste - very smooth powerful complex beer.  will find again.

Bottle from Greens in Atlanta.  Dark brown pour.  Aroma is muted yeast and tobacco.  Tastes are sweet malt, dark fruit, slight sour yeastiness, caramel, cherry, and nuts.  Finishes burnt sugar and light acidic.  Nice enough sipper.
Incredible Raisin Taste. Lost Abbey Never fails. Full of body. Great balance of weight. Thank You again Lost Abbey!!!
Süßer heller Malzantrunk, wenig alkoholisch, Honig. Etwas erdig, das Malz wird dunkler. Recht süß. Karamell, geringe Bitterkeit zum Ende. Nicht so ganz mein Geschmack. /8/8/7/11/7

This is like a "light" version of Lost Abbey Judgement Day which is an epic ale with huge flavors and elements of port.   This one is not as intense.  Notes of caramel and raisins in the nose.  The body is relatively thin.  The flavor is like the nose.  This one can be consumed with big gulps and has a long, pleasant sustain after the gulp.  Mild bitterness.  A pleasure to drink.

Appearance: garnet and ruby under a bready khaki head which fades blotchy and clumpy while sticking to the sides of my glass. Swirls creamy.

Nose: raisins, figs, and prunes  meaty and rich. Nutmeg, allspice, and raisins mingle in the back. Wisps of leather. Tartness of unripe plums, bitter tannins of plum skins. Bourbon barrels  wood and spice. Musky, bretty, leathery, and horsey weaves it all together.

Palate: chewy, rich, and warm in the back. Raisins, figs, and dates both fresh and dried. Leather weaves in and out. The richness continues without being heavy, sweet without being cloying. Raisins and prunes mingle with leather. Tartness lurks along the edges with wood, port, and plum skins. Wintery spices  cumin, ginger, nutmeg, allspice. Heat and spice grabs back of throat with each quaff  bourbon. Warm breath.

Final Thoughts: yummy!!! Love me some Lost Abbey beers. They may be hard to find but well worth the hunt for the success is in the glass.
Pours brownish red with medium off-white head. Aroma is brown sugar, dark fruit, figs, plums, raisins, and candy.  Taste is dark candi sugar, raisins, figs, and a sweet dark fruit finish.  Very nice!

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dark copper with a small very light tan head that has very good retention and leaves some light lacing.  The aroma is caramel, candi sugar, a bit of banana, and some bready yeast.  The initial taste is sweet with some candi sugar, then some raisin, caramel, and a bready yeast.  Medium bodied.  Low carbonation.  Fairly enjoyable beer.

In bottle at The BrewDog Bar, Edinburgh. Pours a hazy red - orange colour with a fair beige head. Biscuity aroma with raisins, figs, inverted sugar, caramel, barley, toffee and leather. Similar biscuity flavour with alcohol, figs and raisins quite prominent. A foamy mouth-feel and moderate carbonation. Quite musty also with lingering leather, hay, wet cardboard,  raisin and green grape flavours. Very nice.
Bottle pours dark amber with hugh tan head.  Sour aroma.  Flavors of acrid raisins with hints of citrus and sweet/sour malts.  Not one of my favorites.

OK, it took a good 15 to 20 minutes to pry off this cork, cork screw out this cork and fish out the bits of shattered cork from the watery product Im doing my best to get at and consume. So you guys sized the wrong cork, cork supplier quality control issues or what? The liquid that finally made it out of the 750mL bottle is ruby red to amber in color and supporting a tan like head. The aroma has spicy yeast, lots of sweet raisins and then a wild yeast like tartness at the edges of the aromatic experience. The taste has bold raisin notes as well as mildly tart wild yeastiness, some yeast spices and brown sugar. It leaves a semi sweet raisin to mild yeasty tartness and near chalky texture into the finish and after taste.

Just finished watching the greatest Rugby game in history of the Cup - Tonga devistates France with unbending defence. I cannot believe what I just watched! Had this for at least a year? Reddish brown with a well defined compact light tan head on top of a reddish brown brew with a healthy dose of sediment. Dubbelish for sure. Caramel, spice, raisins, honey, grass, mild molasses, maybe a mulled orange or something, more of a thick raisin now, some soft fruits - this really improves a lot with time in the glass. When am I going to do a review and not be exhausted? Reviewing this is being done on the bottom half to bottom third of the bottle. Tasty stuff albeit not strong - plenty of subdued qualities. Spices and a weird dry something hit quick, a gingery spice maybe, nutmeg, I dunno. All I know is that in minutes I am going to drink a bunch of hot sauce and then Im going to cook up some Original Flavour Ichiban and then Im going to consider and explore one of lifes great mysteries - bees. Bees and why I cannot ride them. I just want to ride a bee god dammit.  I need a bee harness and I also want to wear a cowboy hat. I also want to sport the wonderful plastic glasses / nose combo. I think my eyes smell. Orangy tang at an underlying level, raisins, raisins, mild pepper, caramel, brown sugar, honey, anise, plastic shoe lace tips in a medeira reduction served by a duck - a proper one - one wearing a top hat. In nature, a top hat on a duck or a weasel signifies uppitiness in the animal kingdom. If its on a worm then the acid has kicked in in a timely manner. No sign of the oxidization that I wrongly assumed would be found with ease, I think people who collect stamps are fucking losers. Tim Hortons patrons - you are all pathetic sheep. Die, please in a manner than humours me. Fudge, belches, some darker fruit stuff. Medium bodied and a forgetful finish. I really hate Tim Hortons. Thanks for all the pollution in my neighbourhood, thanks for making idiots idle their cars for 15 minutes to get your pre-made subpar products. Nice baked donuts - die. It is a plague. Those heart tugging commercials - who the hell does that actually work for? Consistently the worst commercials on my tube TV. I enjoyed this beer I think even though I feel like I was let down. Maybe age has something to do with it - kind of like banging a 45 yr old born again christian mother of 6 with giant fake tits.

750ml bottle from Westroads poured into my Chimay Trappist glass. Bottled 11/23/2010. Pours a cloudy dark nut brown with about 1 finger of tan head. Aroma of figs, fermented fruit and wheat. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Has a nice coffee aftertaste to it. Alcohol is very well hidden. Medium bodied with a thick and creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long, bitter coffee finish. Overall, very good. Something I would like to drink again in the future.

Draught at The Wicked Shamrock, Lompoc, USA.
Clear amber with an off-white head leaving some lacings. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, roasted, dark fruits). Flavor heavy sweet, moderate bitter, in a good balance. Medium to full body, dry, some alcoholic felt.

Aroma:  Malt and some raison.
Palate:  Light-medium body.
Flavor:  Malt, roasty caramel plus some subtle dried fruit/raisin.
Comment:  No flavor evolution. Pretty simple from start to finish.  Would not buy again.  Aged 1 year.

Bottle from Brewdog Bar. Pours reddish-brown and cloudy with thin white lace on the top. The nose has yeast and malt (well duh). The taste has a weird combination of nuts and lemon. Oh, and theres a background note of cake mixture. The palate seems lean like a Flemish red, but for some reason it gets tiring which must mean the finish isnt quite where it should be.

This pours a deep mahogany color with a thick frothy tan head on top.  A thin layer of foam settles on top allowing for a lot of lacing to slide along the sides of the glass after each sip.  The aroma isnt really all that strong but there still seems to be a lot going on with nice subtle nuances.  Raisins, dates, Belgian yeast, caramel, sugars, and a touch of vanilla.  The flavor is just rich enough to offer plenty of substance while still being quite drinkable for 8%.  Everything noted in the aroma seems to show in the taste as well.  It is fairly sweet from some rich malt, dark fruit, and candied fruity notes but it gets slightly dry in the finish with a little bit of spiciness.  Moderate carbonation; a bit prickly on the palate but not overdone.  No thrills or surprises, just a flat out solid dubbel, which I expected coming from Lost Abbey.  Nice stuff.

Appearance:  amber, with a one-finger tan head.   Aroma:  raisins, figs, leather, booze, oatmeal cookies.   Taste: sweet, a little boozy, with a solid malt backbone and notes of raisin, port, toasted brown bread, spicy yeast, and some clove.   Finish: finishes with notes of caramel, wood, leather and a little chocolate over syrupy dark fruits and booze.   Notes: 	In spite of the boozy characteristics, the alcohol was actually well hidden when it came to the taste and palate.  A very nice dubbel, although a tad on the rich side of drinkable.

Serving: 750 ml bottle. Pours a nice amber color with a small light tan head.  The nose is a little woody with light raisin character. Some cedar.  The flavor is spicy wood with a touch of raisin and earth. Light to medium body with average carbonation. Good with lots of character.

On tap at Local option. Aroma: Fresh bread, crisp pale malt and burnt toast. Appearance: Clear, dark gold with lasting foam. Flavors: Nice malt profile with caramel and fresh bread upfront. Palate: Full bodied and fluffy without being sticky. Overall: Very good.
Pours a nice reddish color. Mostly sweet malt and dried fruit, with a little bit of yeast. Really nice beer.

Pours a dark brown color with a small tan head. Sweet malty and slightly yeasty aroma. Some hints of dark fruits. Sweet malty yeasty flavor with hints of caramel and dark fruits. The finish is malty with some yeasty and spicy hints.

Bottle from Harvards in Augusta. Pours dark reddish brown with tan head. Aromas of dark fruits, caramel malts and Belgian yeast. Flavors of raisins, figs, dough and some spices. Medium to full body with moderate carbonation.

Tasted on 7/20/11 from a corked and caged 750mL bottle sent to me as an extra in a trade, this one has a bit of age on it, but there is no bottle date.  Pours fiery red dark amber with an average beige head that slowly recedes to spotty lace with a decent collar and leaving some spotty residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is dominated by malty caramel, grainy cereal, along with some earthy and spicy yeast, brown sugar, and a bit of a vegetal aroma as well.  The flavor is very malty with the caramel, grainy cereal, and brown sugar, burnt bitterness that I didnt really detect on the nose, and the same, very light vegetal flavor.  The body is full and almost creamy with average carbonation and a long burnt bitter and caramel malt finish.
Bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Originally rated on 28.1.2010. Pretty generic Belgian styled ale. Notes of raisin, malts and caramel. Slightly unbalanced.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, & dark fruit; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit (notably plums), raisons, and some spice; Nicely balanced; Pretty good dubbel overall.

750ml bottle - $7.99 at Olde Crabapple Bottle Shoppe in Alpharetta, Georgia.

Bottled on: 11/23/10 (I think thats right, I smudged the date while fighting with the cork).

Appearance: Pours a dark, ruddy-hued body with a tall, foaming head stand, light beige in color.

Smell: Some sweetish notes of dark brown sugar, dark syrup, and a bit of caramel (though upon warming, some cocoa-ish hints awaken). Fruity, slightly boozy, though not caustic hints wrapped up in a spicy herbaceousness like a squirt of Angostura bitters.

Taste: Dark brown sugar-topped toast, with a yeasty, doughy tone about it. Robustly fruity accents of pulverized raisins and varied stone fruits dipped in brandy. Small dash of bitter herbs. A few drops of creme caramel for some late-breaking sweetness, maybe even some slight chocolate as it warms. Low bitterness at best. Smoked cloves, maybe a pinch of black pepper provides some enduring zing. Stays a bit sweet at the end, but, then it manages to close out near-dry and warming.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-high carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel.

Overall: Its a tasty dubbel that, thankfully, doesnt hit hard with any cloying sweetness or enamel-dissolving ethanol bursts. Sadly, I havent had it since that very first Saints club shipment all those many long years ago.

Big Bottle from Binnys SL. Pours deep amber with a decent size tan head/. Aroma of belgian spices, fruit (prodominantly banana) and vanilla. The flavor is smooth, banana, other fruit, citrus, and slight bitter hops in the finish. Great brew.
Bottle. Dark amber with medium off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, yeast, dried fruits, hops, plume and a little raisin.

(750ml bottle) clear still brown, no real carbonation visible. Nose of raisin and dried fruit, paper/oxidation, a bit of maple and nuttiness. Taste of paper, dry grain, medium alcohol, toasty, maple, and dark raisins. Papery finish, way under-carbonated.

This beer is UNBELIEVABLY GOOD! 750 mL bottle, corked and caged, poured into a tulip glass. Pours a deep amber color, thick pillowy head. Lacing covers the entire top of the beer. First sip starts with a slight bitter hoppiness, then gives way to a rich...almost Belgian flavor. Notes of raisin, vanilla, caramel, nuts, coffee. I cant say enough good things about this beer. This is my first try...definitely wont be my last.

Corked and caged 750 ml bottle.  Enjoyed while watching The Longest Day on Memorial Day.   A medium to dark brown pour that is hazy.  Tan head takes a while to subside.  This beer is all about raisin and yeast.  Some very nice fruit, too.  There is very little hop flavor but they do make an impact.  They are citrusy, bitter, and tart and make a nice balance to the sweeter malt and raisin flavors.  Alcohol is tasted but it doesnt really detract here.  This beer is quite tasty!

On tap at Craft and Commerce.  Pours auburn in color with a good amount of beige head.  Nose is some Belgian yeast and spices.  Taste followed the nose with a fair helping of Belgian abbey yeast in there and some spiciness that I could not completely put my finger on.  I like most of the Lost Abbey beers, as the raisin mash they use produces a nice amount of sweetness.  However, that seemed to be missing here.

(bottle). Clear amber color. Medium off white head with good retention. Moderate toast/malt and caramel aroma. Toast/malt flavor with light sweetness. Avg duration. Very light bitter finish with light alcohol. Slick/ light creamy texture. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.
sweet malty aroma,brown/red, light brown foam, hazy, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice sweet malty finish.

Pours brown with a red tinge nice creamy tan head. Smells of toffee, belgian spices, caramel and maybe a touch of vanilla. Raisins, prunes caramel, and creamy but it also has some wine like characteristics very interesting. Mouthfeel is medium and finish is mild with a slight bit of chocolate.

On tap at brewery.  Rich dark amber with thin head.  Plum and raisins in the nose.  Rich malt, coffee, dark fruit.  clean, hop spice is there but still balanced.  not overly sweet or cloying.  Very smooth

Deep brown with white head. Nice aroma of dark fruits, brown sugar, and hint of spice. Dried apples, brown sugar, and Christmas spice in the flavor. Medium palate. Clean, slightly sweet finish. Nice dubbel.

Deep amber in color with a thick creamy head.  Wonderful aromas of raisins, plums, chocolate, and fresh bread.  Full flavors of raisins, plums, dates, chocolate, and yeast.  Rich candied sugars, heavy mouthfeel, and chocolate in the finish.
Dark brown cololured and a bit hazy. Has an off-white head, mostly lasting. Aroma is sweet, faint notes of candy and tobacco. Malty, sweet favor, faint roasted, grain and pepper. Creamy, dry texture.

On tap at the tasting room. It pours dark amber with a tan head. The aroma is fruity and sweet with some candy and yeast. The flavor is potent with fruit, raisins, and alcohol. The finish is very bitter. A nice dubbel that I would try again.

Reddish brown appearance with a thick off white head. Aroma is fruity with a slight yeastiness. Flavor is very sweet with a strong malt presence. Strong fruitiness up front with a mild finish, not cloying at all. Would definitely recommend.

Densely clear, medium-brown colored beer with a bubbly white head.  Really great aroma of dirty wood, something... whatever it is, its really bold and floral, but sweet and inviting.  Smooth, deliciously herbal but sweet flavor thats incredibly easy for a dubbel.  Smooth, and even sessionable!  Go beer!

Aroma - cereal, hay, 
hops - herbs, floral but not much 
yeast - dough
raisin like flavors and bit woody. 

A good nearly great beer by Lost Abbey but I dont think I would need to rush and get another.

Courtesy of Philippe (Bov); corked bottleHazy color, dark mahogany; medium sized head. The caramel aroma is perfumy enough. Good body strength; powerful caramel aroma, with some chocolate and oxidisation; also lightly dusty. Well balanced. The aroma is finer, the flavor is more ordinary.

Bottle thanks to a generous trader. Pours dark brown. Tan head. Nose and taste of mostly dark fruits - sweet raisin, date and figs with roasted malts and Belgian yeast.  Body is a bit on the light side. Good carbonation.

On tap at the SD Taproom, San Diego.  Dark brown pour, beautiful color.  Very little head or lacing.  Weak aroma of dark fruit.  Flavor was dark fruit and a releatively strong level of spicing.  Some clove-like spices and some other spicing as well.  Some plum and raisin like flavors.  Very quad-like in flavor.  Good complementing level of carbonation.  Rich and smooth.  Well crafted.

On tap at The Monk. Pours a murky brown with a small white head. Aroma of bread, earthy spices and roasted malts. Taste brings out some citrus hops with a sweet roasted malt backing. Im enjoying but doesnt jump out at me

Bottle. Pours clear reddish-brown, thin off-white head, ropey to poor lacing. Nose is nutty, with red fruit, lots of anise-laden spice, frankly a bit simple. Flavours of dried fruit, spice, anise. Long finish. Okay.

Copper red with a thin beige head. Aroma is sweet and fruit I sure get the plumb and raisin notes. Flavour is very nice. It is fruity and smooth the raisins give it a nice thickness without bogging it down.  It is slightly vegital it tastes nice but a little odd. Good brew it is interesting but not great.

75 cl bottle. Pours cloudy dark chestnut, with a medium beige head, very fine and lasting lacing. Aroma of raisin, biscuit, caramel, grass, ginger and pepper. Medium-thin body, smooth and velvety. Lightly sweet up-front, with flavors of apple, grape, biscuit, citrus, pepper, and a hint of grass. A very mild tart dryness in the finish.

75cl bottle. Pours a cloudy copper/brown color with a medium tan head. Classic belgian dubbel aromas:dried fruits, malt sweetness, and a nice touch of roastness. The flavor is slighly sweet of molasses with dates, dried figs, and prunes. Not overly sweet though. Great balance. Full body and good carbonation. Overall, a complex and rich brew, deep in flavors without overwhelming. Excellent.

It pours a medium brown with a light tan head that goes up for about 2 fingers but fades quickly. The lacing is so-so, and there is lots of carbonation, big bubbling on a swirl.

The aroma is very light, mostly just sweet malts with a touch of toffee. 

The taste is very light of flavor but its a very full-bodied taste and mouthfeel.

Pours reddish brown with thin white head. Good lacing. Aromas of raisin, figs, bourbon. Moderately sweet. Smooth, almost creamy texture. Moderate sweetness, low bitterness. A bit of carbonation. Far better than I expected this to be.

750 corked n caged bottle- Pours dark ruby red with a nice tan 3 finger head, the head slowly dissipates but never goes away. The aroma is Belgian yeast and sugar with a floral undertone, it is also very tart, nice. The flavor is figs, raisins, candy sugar. Its Belgian with an American twist, it doesnt quite have that Belgian taste that we all love, but it is extraordinary nonetheless, very mellow, smooth, drinkable, shit I could drink this all day. Carbonation is high, body is full and creamy, finish is short, it doesnt stick around making you want to have more. It is not the best beer Ive had, Its not better than the best Belgian beers out there, but is one of the best American interpretations of a Belgian beer.

Poured into a goblet. Bottle is from sometime in 2010 (I think). Theres sure as hell no lack of carbonation in this one. The cork was eager to be freed from the bottle and the first pour yielded twice as much head as liquid.

4.0 A: Nearly clear deep amber/mahogany color. Two and a half fingers of frothy light brown head after second pour. The head is maintained quite well, which is in part thanks to the furious bubbling from the nucleation etches on the bottle of the glass. Theres a decent amount of lacing and if the head were a bit stickier, there would be an incredible amount of lacing. Either way, good here.

4.0 S: Raisin and plum, figs and dates. Belgian yeast spiciness and a dirt earthiness. Crystal malts and candi sugar. Really nice aroma, but could use a steroid injection as it is a bit weak.

4.0 T: The taste mainly follows the nose - lots of raisin, tobacco, and fig. Dates and plum on the next level down. Spicy Belgian yeast, earthy muskiness that almost tastes like a nuttiness, candi sugar, and crystal malts. Pretty damn good.

3.5 M: Light to lighter medium body. Initially overcarbonated, but became good spritzy carbonation after enough swirls. Creamy for how light the body is and super smooth. My only complain here is that the body is too thin. I dont think the thin body was the intent here and I also think that the overcarbonation wasnt intended either. Something makes me think that the two are related.

4.0 D: Well, what can I say. For as much as I hate Tomme Arthur, he can make a pretty good brew when he can get it carbonated. This is right up there with most of its native counterparts. If I could trust that every bottle would be this good (read: carbonated) I might even be willing to pay the premium that Lost Abbey commands. Great taste and good overall except for the lack of body.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-28-2011 22:44:10

Bottled. Thx tkrjukoff
Murky dark amber.
Loads of tropical fruits in both aroma and flavour; apricots and grapes.
Bottle pours a red brown with a tan head. Scent is malt, caramel, and fruits. Taste is sweet and bready bitter. Nice
Reddish brown in color... Candi sugar, malty aroma... Flavor is candi sugar, Belgian yeast fairly prevalent in this one, notes of raisin.... Finish is yeasty... decent beer
Bottle, thanks to tkrjukoff. Amber beer with a small head. Malty vinous aroma, figs, raisins, toffee, nuts, milky notes. Raisins flavor, toffee, figs, a bit vinous.

Pours reddish brown with an averaged sized white head. Lacing is quite good and there seems to be a decent amount of carbonation. Aroma is of lighter malts, fruit, some spices and a tad of sweetness. Flavor is sharper than I expected at first but transitions nicely into a sweet and fruity body with a bitter hoppy finish.
750ml bottle in a shaker.  Pours brown with a lacy beige head.  Aroma of nuts, light malts, spicy yeast, and some light hops.  Flavor about the same.  Smooth texture.  A pretty good dubbel.

This one pours a maroonish brown with a tan head. Smells greatly of dried red fruits and caramel. It has many of the same tastes mixed with some sweet maltiness. Very nice moutfeel and a delight to drink. Best one besides red poppy of the day.

Strong aroma is malty and a little fruity with a yeasty underpinning and hints of caramel. It pours a clear dark mahogany with a thick, pale tan head that sticks around for a little while. Flavor is malty, slightly sweet, slightly sour, with hints of caramel and fruit, the latter mainly grapes and apple. It goes down the hatch smoothly yet leaves a firm, persistent tingle behind. Im glad that this "lost abbey" has been found!

11.01.22 bottle from table and vine mass . Brown and clear minimal white head.  A: Spicy, a bit of brown sugar and grappes. F: Thin to med body finish is sweet and medium long o: Pretty good nice balance.

Shared bottle thx to tkrjukoff, cons 2011-02-04 Billdal 
AR: chocolate, fudge
AP: hazy amber, 3 cm beige head
F: creamy fudge, wee watery feeling, creamy, sour

Pours mahogany with a small tanned small bubbly head leaving nice lace. Malty, hoppy, raisins and madeira aroma. A bit thin body. Crispy fruity mouthfeel. Pleasant fresh, fruity, raisins, caramel, fidges and acetone flavor. Lean nice palate. Finishes tart and a bit sweet.
A really nice, lightly sweet Belgian-style ale. We picked up this bottle in SD in November.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2011 (Bottle) Pours brown with amber highlight. The aroma is phenolic, spicy, toffee-ish malty, light fruity and light earthy. The flavour is light sweet, light bitter and tiny acidic. Earthy, spicy, light fruity, light hoppy and toffee malty. The mouthfeel is tart and light to medium carbonated. Medium bodied.

Pour a deep dark brown colour, with a small tan head that dissipates. Aroma is filled with dark fruit; raisins, dates, and figs just as the description says. Taste is sweet and candy like with not much bitterness present. Full body, soft on the palate, with nice carbonation. Overall an excellent beer, well representative of the style.
2nd April 2009 Cloudy brown beer, low carbonation. Dry palate. Tastes aged - old malt with a hint of raisans. Fairly spirity spicy finish. Okay but not great by the usual Lost Abbey standards.

Bottle.Pours a dull,cloudy reddish brown with a white thick mousse like head.Nose is raisin,plum and cherry with bready notes as well.I also picked up some cocoa on the nose as well.Taste is sweet dark fruits,some chocolate and red wine.Another near flawless interpretation of a particular style by Tomme Arthur and friends.Solid.

750ml bottle.  pours a dark brown with a 2 finger off white head.  sweet raisin and brown sugar aromas with a touch of red grapes.  medium body with decent carbonation.  more sweet sugar notes, some darker malts with dark fruits throughout - figs, raisins, and some lingering cherry.  sweet, burnt finish with notes of caramel and more dark fruits.

bottle.  reddish brown with a small head.  raisins, plums, brown sugar in aroma.  flavors of banana, raisin, dark fruits, brown sugar, some nuts later on.  palate is moderately carbonated for the style with a medium body.  nutty, brown finish with a dry palate.  the right amount of sweetness.

Bottle; Pour is dark brown with an off white head - fairly clear. Loved the aromas out of the bottle; Raisins, Figs, Brown Sugar - Not exactly traditional , however. Theres a tart cherry acetic quality to this brew, and it couples with that caramel, figs, raisins - Carbonation is on the heavier side. Nice drinkable quality, but it doesnt *quite* work for me.

pours a mahogany color with a large foamy tope colored head. Nose is mulling spices, candied apples, and licorice. Taste is the same with some boozy port / vinous notes, and a toffee like finish. Pretty good, alcohol is apparent and carbonation is on the high side.

On tap at the Cheeky Monk. Pours a dark maroon body with a two finger maroon colored head. Candy sugar, a bit of yeast, raisins, and a brown Belgian aroma. Dark Belgian ale flavor with candy sugar and raisins. Sweet foamy finish and aftertaste.

750ml bottle. Dark  brown pour,  almost black. Thick bubbly head with a nice oily lacing. Somewhat malty aroma with hints of raisins and dried fruit. The  flavor has the raisins but with a slight oak kick to it. Somewhat heavy on the  palate, but very tasty.

{thoughts} Rustic and aged, though a bit bothered by peppery alcohols and a stabbing acetone quality.

{elements} Clear, effervescent, ruby-brown hue; frothy, light tan head. Dusty, Belgian-style aroma with cherry pits; lightly acetic and alcoholic, lightly papery. Dry, medium-full acidity (cherries and carbonic), low bitterness; nutty with a hint of vanilla and some fruity-sharp acetone qualities. Full carbonation, medium bodied, silky texture.
 75 cl bottle, probably from 2007.
75cl, American brew, with raisins, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, sweet and spicy, yet balanced, clear, rocky head, good brew, yet expensive!

Interesting beer but not one of Lost Abbeys best. Lots of dark fruit, very raisiny, a bit too carbonated. I enjoyed this with a second version of new years eve dinner--it went well with the tarts--but Im not sure this ones really worth the money.

medium brown large white head.  nose of sweet malt and a near berry like component from the yeast.  medium to low carbonation for the style.  low bitterness before some special b sweet/roasty flavors and a lot of esters.  the residual sweetness is average to slightly above.  a touch of alcohol that distracts and provides a touch of an acrid aftertaste.  overall a fine, if not exemplary dubbel

from erzbierschof.ch - slightly hazy reddish-brown colour with a persistent beige foam; deep aroma of tea and raisins, marzipan, some sweetness and a velvety mouthfeel, low bitterness and full-bodied; long malty and biscuity aftertaste with lingering notes of raisins - wonderfully brewed
750mL bottle, pours dark orangey amber with a beige head. Aroma of caramel, spices and a dry character. Flavour of dried fruits, smooth caramel, with a dry palate. Solid.
Pours hazed amber with a thick creamy beige head. Aroma of caramel, cherry, raisins and other darker fruit. Taste is bready, mild spice, dark fruit. Very smooth texture, soft carbonation.

on tap at the lost abbey tasting room. pours a dark, hazy, brownish burgandy with a thick, creamy, beige head. aroma is damn nice with sweet raisins, figs, and dark berries with notes of sweet toffee, licorice, and belgian spices. flavor is delicious with big, sweet, slightly tart red fruits, brandied raisins, figs, and belgian yeast backed by nutty malts, spices, and caramel. palate is medium bodied with high carbonation and a long, dry, sweet finish. overall, a damn nice dubbel.
Pours dark ruby with a thin ivory head. Notes of dark fruit, red wine, wood, spice and earth. A very good Belgium. Great finish for the style.

Bottled 75cl. Murky nut brown beer with a creamy light beige head. Port, raisins, plums, toffee and luscious malts throughout. Balanced and delicious. Subtle carbonation. Medium to full bodied. Very drinkable. Not much lacework. Long finish which is mainly reminiscent of walnuts. A very good interpretation of the style. Flawless.
Dark amber with a medium beige creamy head. Aroma is caramel, raisin, chocolate. Full body with low carbonation. In mouth is sweet, chocolate caramel, fruits. Pretty good beer.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2010 750ml bottle.  Worthless label description.  Thick, practically opaque brown-burgundy color.  Soapy, lacy beige head.  Mellow dark Belgian yeast aroma.  The raisin flavor is apparent, but melds perfectly in with the style.  Mellow carbonation in comparison to its Belgian role-models.  Still quite a nice beer, subdued and subtle. Easy drinking, hides the alcohol superbly.  Pretty solid, well executed.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2015 Bottle at the Funky 6. Pours a semi-clear, amber-brown with a dense, off-white head. Malty, sugary aroma with caramel, raisins and anis. Very sweet, with malts, lightly roasted, more caramel, toffee and plenty of ripe, dark fruits. Medium bodied with an oily consistency and average carbonation. Finishes sweet, warm and with lingering fruit and toffee notes. Good beer. (August 2010, score: 3.7)Draft at Craft Beer Co. Clapham during Route CBC - London. Pours clear amber with a creamy, off-white head. The nose holds meaty malts, burnt herbs, orange rind. Medium sweet flavor with more meat, light ham, toast, moderate caramel. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Sweet finish with toasted malts, light caramel, earth, honeyed ham. Nice one. (October 2015, score: 3.5)

On Tap at Uptown Brothers, Denver 14/09/2010
Some roast aroma. Dark coloured smooth on the palate strong in alcohol hoppy and fruity with a hint of dryness in a bitter coffee roast finish.
Funky raisin aroma, not good funk. Clear ochre brown, thick head. Overripe apple and very old musty raisin flavor, dryish for the style. Alcohol pretty noticeable.

750 ml. bottle from a local wine shop. Very effervescent, with a head that didnt last long. Translucent dark brown color. Looks like a decent Dubbel, but I find the style to be difficult to rate. Alcohol is poking through a little bit, but the raisins are shining through quite well. Figs are also noticed, in the aroma, but the raisins are just insane. The aroma is not very nuanced in terms of aroma, but oh well. Wow, the figs and raisins dominate the taste. The alcohol is just too much. There seems to be a bit of a date flavor popping out. The biggest problem -- the alcohol. I find the alcohol to be a bit too hot. The flavors are great, but that alcohol...damn. Rather chewy texture, despite the alcohol.

9/28/10 notes: Bottle.  Confusing beer to me, overall to sweet and heavy.  Color is murky light brown, and aroma has lots of dried fruit and candi sugar.  Body is thin.  Flavor is sweet blend of dried fruit with touches of sugar and brown breadiness.

murky brown pour with nice carbonation. the flavors werent as bold as I had expected, rather they are subtle to the point that this should be the first beer you drink so as not to overpower the flavors.  delicious and complex, the flavor seemed to peak at a certain temperature and then fade away again.  I like the bolder lost abbey offerings so I was a little disappointed

Bottle, shared with Parksy and Josephson. Dark brown with golden highlights and an enormous bubbly brown head. Sweet raisinaroma, soft yeast. Very malty, heaps of sweet figs, prunes, raisins, subtle spice. A beautiful dubbel!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a New Belgium globe glass.

A: Smells just like raisins, with a bit of molasses, but not too much. You can tell this is going to be a malty beer.
S: Pours a deep brown with a foamy beige head that doesnt disappear.
T: Big and malty with a nice raisin finish. No trace of alcohol, which is surprising once I saw that it is 8% abv.
M: Very well carbonated and medium bodied.
D: For what it is, its pretty drinkable. Not overpowering in sweetness, but it hides the alcohol quite well. The best Lost Abbey beer Ive tried to date!

UPDATED: APR 18, 2013 Draft at Jerrys. Dark amber with good, foamy, tan head, fine legs / Nose of dark fruit, smoke, pine / Medium to full body, sweet & syrupy, some hop balance turning dryer on the good finish / Flavors of raisin, date, roast grain, brown sugar, clove, nutmeg / A rich and sweet dubbel.

Color is medium brown with ruby highlights and a lasting beige head. Strong malty aroma, sweet, alcohol fumes. Sweet raisin flavor dominates, followed by noticeable alcohol yet still drinkable. Full bodied, lasting flavor. Kind of like a quad light.

I havent been too impressed with Lost Abbey beers. With such a great concept and package the beer doesnt quite measure up. Real Abbey ales have a true depth and character that I suppose comes from hundreds of years of brewing. While Lost Abbey beers are better than most. It seems like they are missing the mark. This beer was good. I like the use of raisins. The flavors are very separate from each other. Almost like you added all the ingredients and alcohol and mixed it up and bottled it. Overall the beer seems rushed and needed more time to develop more complex flavors. Alcohol too prominent.

Clear dark brown body that sits beneath a thick, creamy, tan head that laces nicely as well.
Complex malty aroma - dark fruits, molasses, candy and raisins.
Rich sweet flavor that follows the aroma.
Tasty!

Draft. Brown approaching black body. Frothy, off-white head, rapidly diminishing. The aroma has notes of roasted malts (with a hint of burnt malts), bread, nuts herbs, resin, earthiness, barnyard and smoke. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body with a watery texture that turns sticky. Lively carbonation. Very nice aroma, but the flavor doesnt live up to the aromas billing. The thin mouthfeel that turns syrupy is a let-down. Too bad.

arrr, the north sea where the men smell like fish! arrr arrr!! .. . pours a murked out tan, decent light lacing .. . aha just as i suspected .. . light candi sugar, brown sugar and light cellar dust .. . looks like the hamster fell off the wheel .. . ok stuff i guess- could be more carbonated and more complex .. . Yes, it says the situation is a microcosm juxtaposed against and created by the macrocosm of the universe. And there my neighbor, you have your answer. ..

Brown bottle, 1 pint 9,4 ounces, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on August 7 2010; eye: amber with a bronze hue, clear, no effervescence, beige head that turns into a tiny ring, no lacing; nose: fig, malt, molasses, yeast, caramel, tobacco; mouth: fig, malt, molasses, yeast, caramel, tobacco, finale in fig with presence of malt, medium body, below-average carbonation, mildly sweet, slick texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte 9,4 onces, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 7 août 2010; il : cuivrée avec une teinte bronze, claire, pas deffervescence, mousse beige qui se transforme en un petit anneau, pas de dentelle; nez : figue, malt, mélasse, levure, caramel, tabac; bouche : figue, malt, mélasse, levure, caramel, tabac, finale en figue avec présence de malt, corps moyen, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement sucrée, texture coulante; en résumé : bien

750ml bottle. Pours out a hazy orange color with a beige head. The nose is full of citrus, spices, malty and slight funk as well. Flavors were malty, sweet, slight citrus notes present as well and spices. Sweetness was followed by a touch sour finish. Different beer in a good way.
Bottle, all round tastings. Raisons, soft carbanation, caramel, perfume, herbs, spices, lemony dry finish, moderate bitterness, fruits and a toffee nose.

A Mes rate. Bottle thanks to Thomas.Unattractive murky red brown with a huge frothy off white head. Pretty rank sickly sweet aroma. Lots of caramalt and toffee apples. Similar flavour. Really sweet and yeasty. Some rum and raisin ice cream. Sticky and chewy and pretty poor to be honest. I cant even be bothered writing full notes.

750ml bottle.  The pour was cloudy deep brown.  The nose was sweet malt and dark fruit.  The taste was interesting, slightly sweet and slightly bitter.  The flavors were sweet malt, raisin, dark fruits, spice, and candies.
A decent offering, well worth the money and id possibly get it again. Just didnt knock my socks off. a little weird, candi sugar, spices, decent.

750ml. Pours brown with ruby highlights, with a lasting fluffy beige head. Aroma is quite spicey, with some dark malts, and something earthy. Flavor is raisins, dark fruit, and quite a bit of spices. Some alcohol on the finish. Interesting beer.

Pour is a nice dark ruby red to umber. Medium plus off-white head with good retention. 

Lots of spice and raisin in the nose. Cinnamon, candied-raisin, clove, figs, and rye bread. 

Taste is huge raisin, molasses, caramel, and baking spices. Decent layering overall. Finish is medium and very malty but with a good bit of bitter balance. 

Palate is lighter than expected, but very pleasant. Carbonation is noticeable for sure, in a good way, alcohol is well balanced. 

Overall quite drinkable and enjoyable.
Hazy auburn brown color with thin white foam. Malty yet yeasty nose. Tastes very much like a hefeweizen with some some peppery spiciness and dark fruit
Spicy aromas, malty with hints of caraml. Pours dark amber with no head. Malty with a slight tart funkiness, spicy hops, caramell flavors
750 ml bottle at Brickskellar, shared with Freddie.  Brown, edge head.  Aroma of cocoa.  Taste starts with cocoa, and slight sourness, dry, bitter finish.  Interesting.

On tap at the Sunset Grill in Boston. Slightly cloudy dark amber color with slight tan head. Almost no lace. Nice aroma, malty sweet candy, dried fruit and yeasty bread.  Flavor follows aroma, with noticeable alcohol, though less than Angels Share.

750 ml bottle via trade with fidelis83- thanks again, Jeremiah!  Pours a cloudy plum-brown color with almost no head.  Aroma of raisins, figs, candi sugar, caramel malts, yeast, brown sugar, and mild spices.  Flavor follows suit closely, just not as nice as the aroma.  Despite the 8% ABV, there seems to be a little alcohol burn along with the heavy fruit, sugar, and spice flavors.  Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a sticky mouthfeel.  I was a little disappointed with this one based on other stuff Ive had from LA.

Dark read amber with a beautiful thick light-brown head that leaves a good lacing. Metallic, malty aroma. Taste of caramel, malt, alcohol and acidity. Medium body and sticky. Well balanced and very drinkable.
